AIM – Familiarisation with Networking Devices 
 
Experiment 1 in data communication typically involves identifying, 
understanding the function of, and sometimes physically handling 
common networking devices like hubs, switches, routers, bridges, 
modems, and NICs, learning about their roles (e.g., connecting 
devices, routing traffic, bridging networks) and basic components like 
cables and connectors, often using tools like a crimping tool for cable 
preparation and software like Packet Tracer for simulations. The goal 
is to grasp the foundational hardware and its physical connections in 
building a network. 
 
Key Devices & Components Covered 
1) Hub (Layer 1 – Physical Layer) 
 

About Hub: 
A hub is a basic networking device used to connect multiple 
computers in a LAN. It sends (broadcasts) the incoming data to all 
ports, so every device receives the data even if it is meant for only 
one device. This causes more traffic and collisions, so hubs are slower 
than switches. 
2) Switch (Layer 2 – Data Link Layer) 
 
About Switch: 
A switch is an advanced device that connects multiple devices in a 
network and forwards data only to the correct destination device 
using MAC addresses. It reduces collisions and improves speed 
compared to a hub. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 

 
3) Router (Layer 3 – Network Layer) 
 
About Router: 
A router connects different networks (example: your home network 
to the internet). It forwards data packets based on IP addresses and 
helps in routing traffic efficiently. 
 
4) Modem (Modulator–Demodulator) 
 
About Modem: 
A modem converts digital signals from your computer into analog 
signals (and vice versa) so it can travel through ISP lines 
(telephone/fiber/cable). It is mainly used for internet connectivity. 
 
 

 
 
5) NIC (Network Interface Card) 
 
About NIC: 
A NIC is a hardware component that allows a computer to connect to 
a network. It can be wired (Ethernet) or wireless (Wi-Fi). Every NIC 
has a unique MAC address. 
 
6) Bridge (Layer 2 Device) 
 
About Bridge: 
A bridge connects two LAN segments and filters network traffic using 
MAC addresses. It helps reduce unnecessary traffic between 
segments and improves performance. 
 
 
 

 
 
7) Gateway 
 
About Gateway: 
A gateway connects networks that use different protocols and works 
like a translator between them. It is often the entry/exit point of a 
network. 
 
8) RJ45 Crimping Tool + Cable Tester + RJ45 Connectors 
 
About Crimping Tool & RJ45: 
A crimping tool is used to attach an RJ45 connector to a UTP cable 
(Cat5/Cat6) to make Ethernet cables. Cable testers are used to check 
whether the cable wiring is correct and working properly.
